awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Sub-orbital Ballooning System (SBS) for Earth and Space Observations, Meteorological Applications, and Scientific Studies
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a sub-orbital ballooning system for Earth and space observations, meteorological applications, and scientific studies. Currently, the only way to access this region is via rocketry, which does not allow more than a few minutes of access.  The proposed technology may remove the hurdles in accessing the mesospheric sub-orbital region for a prolonged duration and allow balloon-based payload launch support at a cost less than 50% of the current sub-orbital launch costs. In addition, the proposed technology may intensify the exploitation of mesosphere for scientific research, exploration, and security purposes. It is estimated that the proposed system may save >$1M/sq.km/y in capital expenses and >$2M/sq.km/y in operational expenses for telecommunication service providers, making them lower-cost with wide coverage for next generation networks (5G/6G). In addition, the proposed technology may fulfill the remote sensing and technology demonstration needs of the private sector and military needs for communication and persistent surveillance, as well as the needs of federal agencies, academia, and the scientific community in better understanding the mesosphere and its effects on the Earth, which otherwise is not feasible using existing technologies of rocketry or high-altitude ballooning. A goal for the technology is to enable low-cost space exploration that will open doors to many who have no access to space today due to technological limitations and cost constraints, accelerating space exploration.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a sub-orbital ballooning system for Earth and space observations, meteorological applications, and scientific studies. The technology leverages advancement in ballooning technology by incorporating previous research on size control by energy and mass transfer to reach higher altitudes throughout the mesosphere and up to the edge of space (von Kármán line). The artificial intelligence (AI) powered system is designed to sense the environment, understand the ballooning transport needs, and fulfil energy demands facilitating the inflation or deflation of the balloon envelop. This capability enables the raising or lowering of the balloon’s altitude without bursting the balloon. The proposed technology performs precise altitude control that enables access to the sub-orbital region for prolonged durations. The proposed technology was designed to address the technology gap and market needs followed by proof-of-concept demonstrations on scaled prototypes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
SpaceLoon has created an entire new field of research and technology development, SpaceLoon is enabling an access to the Mesospheric region of the atmosphere for long duration that was previously not feasible due to technological limitations. It is the NSF I-Corps program through which SpaceLoon started this journey started having conversations with potential customers, and found them, found technology early adopters, partners, collaborators, and more importantly the world class team members.

The major outcome of the project is that we have conducted more than 1300 customer discovery interviews across the nations (US, UAE, Israel, Australia, UK/Europe) after starting with the I-corps program workshop. Through these conversations we found our beachhead market segment for space technology testing to commercial, academic, and government customers. SpaceLoon has market validated it’s potential to transform the space industry as we know it.

We have more than 200 conversations with the technology testing service providers who are our potential early technology adopters. Our technology early adopters also include scientists and technologists from government and academic section with whom we had so far more than 500 conversations.

These efforts lead SpaceLoon to win first SBIR Phase-I award from NSF. SpaceLoon is building world class team and now has Board of Directors with 3-members, Board of Business Advisors with 3-members, and a Board of Science Advisors with 2-members. SpaceLoon is evolving from a single founder to two co-founders with deep background experience (15+ years) in their fields. Senior Directors of SpaceLoon have 30+ years of experience individually. All the advisory members of SpaceLoon’s team have more than 20 years of experience individually. Including full-time and part-time employees, SpaceLoon’s current team size total is 15, and it’s growing. All this after the NSF I-Corps cohort.

SpaceLoon is working on submitting 7 proposals in the next 4 months to various agencies, totaling of $3M+ potential. Beyond grant proposals, SpaceLoon has raised so far around $200K investment from private and other government agencies. SpaceLoon has an active NSF SBIR Phase-I grant $256K, and currently initiating its efforts towards raising angel investment in the coming months.

The impact of the NSF I-Corps program is that the technology seed that was rooted in the university is now sprouting in the society. At the start of the I-Corps program, SpaceLoon was at the concept stage and now is a well-established company with multiple awards and customers.

 


Last Modified: 02/28/2023
Modified by: Ibrahim N Tansel
